# 1 Overview

The P800 core load store unit (LSU) module records programs order of load / store request, and executes out-of-order after payloads issued from backend (BE). As shown in the figure 1 below, BE needs allocate entry of load order buffer (LOB) or store request queue (SRQ) in dispatch stage. After out-of-order scheduler in BE, address payload issued to LSU and calculate virtual address for arbitration of L1 data cache (L1DC) and DTLB access. Virtual page number of all request translated to physical page number by DTLB. When DTLB miss, corresponding entry moved to translate miss queue (TMQ) and replay after DTLB refill wakeup. L1DC access of address payload request follows virtual-indexed physical-tagged (VIPT) and speculative access. The L1DC miss of load request lead to allocation of Data Pending Buffer (DPB), and detected RAW of load request lead to allocation of load hazard queue (LHQ). Data of write back has three sources: L1DC hit response, L2cache refill and RAW forwarding. Request deallocated in-order from LOB / SRQ when execute done or exception raised, and send commit info to Reorder Buffer (ROB).

Key features are listed as below:

- This version of LSU module consists of AGU, AHP, DTLB, L1DC, EHU, and LSQ.

- **Load-to-use latency:** 

  - 4 cycles for cache line hit & STB full hit & RAW forwarding.
  - Asynchronize for cache miss or STB partial hit.
  
- **Throughput**

  - 4x 64-bits Load / Store address payload input channel for scalar.

  - 2x 512-bits Load / Store address payload input channel, and 2x 64-bits Load / Store address payload input channel for vector.

  - 4x L1DC access channel.

  - 4x 64-bits write back channel and 2x 512-bits write back channel.

  - 2x 512-bits Store data payload channel and 2x 64-bits Store data payload channel.

  - 2x Store L1DC write access channel.

- **Decomposed LSQ**

  Queues are decomposed based on function & request status

  - Load Order Buffer (LOB)
  - Load Hazard Queue (LHQ)
  - Load Speculation Queue (LSPQ)
  - Store Request Queue (SRQ)
  - Store Data Queue (SDQ)
  - Translate Miss Queue (TMQ)
  - Resource Hazard Queue (RHQ)

- **L1 Data Cache**

  - Inclusive L1DC & write-back policy to L2
  - L1DC control logic incorporated in LSU
  - Prefetch supported with various modes
  - ***Please refer to cache design spec for more info.***
  
- **Other supported features:** 

  - In-Order allocate/dispatch from BE to LOB / SRQ
  - Out-of-Order address/data payload issue from BE to AGU
  - Uses VIPT structure for L1DC access.
  - Speculative load access
  - LD <-> ST hazard prediction, detection and forwarding
  - RVWMO & RVTSO memory model supported
  - ROB external replay detection (for speculative load)



## 1.1 Key Parameters

| Parameter                                |    P600    |                          P800                           | Note                      |
| ---------------------------------------- | :--------: | :-----------------------------------------------------: | ------------------------- |
| Load Order Buffer (LOB) Depth            |     16     |                           80                            | 20 * 4 slices             |
| Load Hazard Queue (LHQ) Depth            |    ---     |                           64                            | 32 * 2 slices             |
| Load Speculation Queue (LSPQ) Depth      |    ---     |                           64                            | 16 * 4 slices             |
| Store Request Queue (SRQ)                |     16     |                           64                            | 32 * 2 slices             |
| Store Data Queue (SDQ)                   |     16     |               64 (64-bits) + 8 (512-bits)               | 32 * 2 slices for 64-bits |
| Resource Hazard Queue (RHQ)              |    ---     |                           16                            | 4 * 4 slices              |
| Address Translate Miss Queue (TMQ) Depth |     8      |                           32                            | 16 * 2 slices             |
| Number of pipeline                       |     2      |                            4                            |                           |
| load throughput                          | 2x 64-bits | 4x 64-bits for scalar &<br />max 2x 512-bits for vector |                           |
| store throughput                         | 1x 64-bits | 4x 64-bits for scalar &<br />max 2x 512-bits for vector |                           |

Note: all parameter is tentative, exact values await performance simulator results.



g## 1.2 Abbreviations

| Abbreviation | Full Description                           |
| ------------ | ------------------------------------------ |
| LSU          | Load Store Unit                            |
| AGU          | Address Generation Unit                    |
| DTLB         | Data Translate Look-aside Table            |
| LOB          | Load Order Buffer                          |
| LHQ          | Load Hazard Queue                          |
| LSPQ         | Load Speculation Queue                     |
| SRQ          | Store Request Queue                        |
| SDQ          | Store Data Queue                           |
| AHP          | Address Hazard Predictor                   |
| RHQ          | Resource Hazard Queue                      |
| TMQ          | (Address) Translate Miss Queue             |
| DPB          | Data Pending Buffer                        |
| L1DC         | L1 Data Cache                              |
| MSHR         | Miss Status Handling Register              |
| NC           | Non-Cacheable (IO requests)                |
| VA           | Virtual Address                            |
| VI           | Virtual Index (lower address bits from VA) |
| PA           | Physical Address                           |
| PT           | Physical Tag (higher address bits from PA) |
| ID           | Index                                      |

## 2.2 Pipeline Stage Description

### 2.2.1 Load Requests

In general, all new load requests allocate the LOB in program order during the dispatch stage for memory order checks. Meanwhile, speculation confidence value is read from AHP by partial PC and buffered in LOB. The address payload is issued to LSU out-of-order from scalar BE and in-order from vector BE, once all source operands are ready. AGU arbitrates accessible address payload from scalar BE or vector BE, and calculates the full VA by carry select adder. After arbitration of new request and replay request, VA payload is sent to access DTLB and L1DC. And offset of address is transfered to next stage for hazard check. If DTLB hits and validity, the request is then checked for IO property and wait in LOB for transferred to L1DC if the check is positive. Requests with DTLB miss are pushed to TMQ and wait for DTLB refill before sending replays to DTLB. And requests are detected with L1DC / DTLB / iPRF bank conflict sent to resource hazard queue (RHQ) and replay quickly. For non-IO and DTLB-hit requests, their addresses are checked against LOB and SRQ for any address hazard, including RAR and RAW. Requests with RAW hazards spotted or presumed are killed and wait for wakeup in the LHQ before being selected and replayed to L1DC. If there's no hazard detected and L1DC miss occurs, request is transferred to Data Pending Buffer (DPB) for miss handling. LOB sends ROB done and update speculation confidence value of AHP when PA for all older instructions obtained and checked.

<center>Figure 2. Load Requests Execution Flow</center>



- <u>**Before AGEN: LOB Allocate & AHP Read**</u>

  - **LOB**

    - BE accesses LOB in dispatch stage, and LOB returns allocated LOB ID. No address payload received.
    - The allocated LOB ID is returned in the current allocation cycle, and the LOB entry is updated in the next cycle.

  - **AHP**

    - Speculation confidence value is read by partial PC and buffered in LOB.

    

- <u>**AGEN: VA Calculation & Request Arbitration**</u>

  - **AGU**
  
    - Arbitration for scalar request and vector request.
    - Full VA calculation by carry select adder.
  
  - Arbitration for new request and replay request
  
    
  
- **<u>DC0: L1DC/DTLB Access & Partial Hazard check</u>**

  - L1DC data & tag RAM is read in L1DC.
  
  - **DTLB** 
  
    - Matches hit entry with VPN.
    - Misalign exception info is sent to EHU for handling.
    - ***Please refer to MMU design spec for more info.***
  
  - **SRQ**
  
    - VA inclusive / overlap check between in-flight request and entry of each SRQ slice, for RAW forwarding.
    - The youngest entry with hit address is identify in each SRQ slice.
    - Offset part of RAW hazard check is performed.
  
  - **LOB**
  
    - Offset part of RAR hazard check is performed.
  
    
  
- <u>**DC1: DTLB PA Output & LSQ Hazard Check**</u>

  - **DTLB**

    - DTLB generates complete physical address.
    - IO property check.
    - TLB exception info is sent to EHU for handling.
  - **L1DC**

    - RAM output.
    - ***Please refer to cache design spec for more info.***
  - **LOB**
    - RAR hazard check is performed by PT.
  - **SRQ**
    - RAW hazard check is performed using AHP output, and compare hazard check results between in-flight requests and entries of each SRQ slice.
    - Entry with older ROB index and PA not ready is recorded, and current load request marked as need to be sent to LSPQ.
    - PT check for RAW forwarding, and forwarding result sent to DFF for use. 
  - **TMQ**
    - Request with DTLB miss allocate TMQ.
  - **RHQ**
    - Request with L1DC no-ready allocate RHQ.
  - **LSPQ**
    - Request with speculation status allocate LSPQ.

    - Recorded SRQ tag bits are updated.

  

- **<u>DC2: PRF Write Back & Hazard Handle</u>**

  - The physical register file (PRF) writes back if there is a L1DC hit or RAW forwarding is valid. 

  - **L1DC**

    - True hit / miss info available from L1DC.
    - **L1DC request is killed if :**
      - DTLB PA is not valid.
      - IO property is checked out upon the first DTLB access.
      - RAW hazard is detected.
    
  - **LOB**
  
    - Entry with write back is marked as execution done.
    
    - Entry with all older instructions obtained and checked, i.e. need not allocate LSPQ, is marked as ROB check pass.
    
  - **LHQ**
  
    - Request with RAW hazard allocate LHQ.
    - RAW hazard flag bits and recorded SRQ tag are updated.
  
  - **RHQ**
  
    - Request with L1DC bank conflict allocate RHQ.
    - Oldest entry of each slice is selected to LSQ replay.
  
  - **DTLB**
  
    - PMP exception info is sent to EHU for handling.
  
    
  
- **<u>After DC2:</u>** 
  
  - DTLB awakes TMQ entry when refill and TMQ sends replay request to the arbiter.
  - DPB allocation, refill and write back.
  - LHQ selects the oldest RAW replay ready entry for LSQ replay.
  - TMQ selects the oldest DTLB miss replay ready entry for LSQ replay.
  - LOB sends IO load request to L1DC when it is the oldest request of LOB and SRQ.
  - LOB sends ROB done when execution done and ROB check pass.
  - LOB updates ROB replay state when new hazard or snoop / ECC detected.
  - Speculation confidence value is updated by ROB replay info.
  - Exception info is sent to LSQ and ROB from EHU in DC3.
  



### 2.2.2 Store Requests

In general, all new store requests allocate the SRQ in program order during the dispatch stage for memory order checks. The address payload is issued to LSU out-of-order from scalar BE and in-order from vector BE, once all source operands are ready. Like load request, after access AGU and request arbiter, VI of store is sent to access tag RAM of L1DC, and DTLB is accessed to obtain the physical address (PA). If DTLB hits, the request is then checked for IO property, and wait in SRQ for transfer to L1DC if the check is positive. Requests with DTLB miss are pushed to TMQ and waits for DTLB refill before sending replays to DTLB. And requests are detected with L1DC / DTLB bank conflict sent to resource hazard queue (RHQ) and replay quickly. For DTLB-hit requests, their address are checked against LOB and SRQ for WAR and un-detected RAW. PA is also sent to L1DC to make sure the accessed cacheline is in L1DC, and L1DC response the result of check to mark current store request. And a L1DC miss in current stage could accelerate the L2cache refill before the data access and write to L1DC. Requests wait in SRQ until it be the oldest store and data in SDQ is ready. After all older load instructions obtained and non-speculative checked, SRQ send store request to DTB and ROB done signal to BE.

<center>Figure 3. Store Requests Execution Flow</center>



- <u>**Before AGEN: SRQ Allocate**</u>
  - **SRQ**
    - BE accesses SRQ in dispatch stage, and SRQ returns allocated SRQ ID. No payload received.
    - The allocated SRQ ID is returned in the current allocation cycle, and the SRQ entry is updated in the next cycle.




- <u>**AGEN: VA Calculation & Request Arbitration**</u>

  - **AGU**
    - Arbitration for scalar request and vector request.
    - Full VA calculation by carry select adder.
  - Arbitration for new request and replay request
  
  
  
- **<u>DC0: L1DC/DTLB Access & Partial Hazard check</u>**

  - L1DC tag RAM is read in L1DC.
  - **DTLB** 
    - Matches hit entry with VPN.
    - Misalign exception info is sent to EHU for handling.
    - ***Please refer to MMU design spec for more info.***
  - **SRQ**
    - Offset part of WAW hazard check is performed.
  - **LOB**
    - Offset part of WAR hazard check is performed.

​		

- <u>**DC1: LSQ Hazard Check**</u>

  - **DTLB**
    - DTLB generates complete physical address.
    - IO property check.
    - TLB exception info is sent to EHU for handling
  - **L1DC**
    - RAM output.
    - ***Please refer to cache design spec for more info.***
  - **LOB**
    - WAR hazard check is performed by PT.
    - ROB replay bit of LOB entry is set when undetected RAW found.
  - **SRQ**
    - WAW hazard check is performed by PT.

  - **TMQ**
    - Request with DTLB miss allocate TMQ.
  - **RHQ**
    - Request with L1DC no-ready allocate RHQ.

  

- **<u>DC2: Store Issue Prepare</u>**

  - Store requests is sent to STB in next cycle if

    - All older Load address checked.
    - It is Oldest store request.
    - No WAR hazard flag or exception.
    - ROB wakeup signal has received.

  - **L1DC**

    - L1DC hit / miss response return to SRQ.
    
  - **RHQ**

    - Request with L1DC bank conflict allocate RHQ.
    - Oldest entry of each slice is selected to LSQ replay.
    
  - **DTLB**

    - PMP exception info is sent to EHU for handling

    

- **<u>After DC2:</u>** 

  - State flag bits are updated when hazard wakeup / new hazard detected.
  - ROB done is sent to BE and the allocated bit of AHP entry is cleared when L1DC response.
  - Exception info is sent to LSQ and ROB from EHU.

# 4 Sub-Modules

**Acceptable for storage in RAM:** Response value valid in next cycle after access is acceptable.



## 4.1 Address Generation Unit (AGU)

### 4.1.1 Features

AGU is used to calculate the virtual address for a given memory request. It takes a base address and offset as the two operands and performs addition to obtain the virtual address. Furthermore, it's also used to select the address payload from scalar source or vector source.

**Source Arbitration**

* Priority: 512-bits vector address payload > scalar address payload > 64-bits vector address payload.
* When two 512-bits channel used simultaneously, other narrow channels banned and without ready signal return to scalar / vector BE.

**Address Generation**

- Virtual address [63:0] calculation is based on a 64-bits carry select adder (CSA).
- 4 CSAs for 4 pipelines.
- For simplify the address overlap check, the low 3-bits of VI extended to an 8-bits mask according to request type. It shows the low 8 accessed bytes.

## 4.2 Address Hazard Predictor (AHP)

### 4.2.1 Features

AHP is used to decide load request whether bypass older address-unknown store request and speculative write back. It's indexed by the load's partial PC[12:0] and has the numbers of 8192 entries. Each entry buffers the speculation confidence of corresponding load request.

When a load request perform address hazard check in SRQ, the older and address-overlap store request seem as RAW detected, but the older and address-unknown store request make this load request in a state of speculation. Whether bypass the older address-unknown store request and speculative write back is according to the speculation confidence. Load request need pending until older stores get PAs when the speculation confidence is subpar, and bypass older store request opposite.

All entries' speculation confidence reset to zero initial and reset per 2^20 cycles. A detected ROB replay make the speculation confidence decrease, and a commit without ROB replay marked make the speculation confidence increase. 



### 4.2.2 Datatype

|      Data Payload      |        Number of Entry        |       Width per Endtry       | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                                           |
| :--------------------: | :---------------------------: | :--------------------------: | :---------------------------: | ----------------------------------------------------- |
| Speculation Confidence | 2^RRV64_LSU_AHP_PC_WIDTH (13) | RRV64_LSU_AHP_CONF_WIDTH (1) |               Y               | Speculation confidence of corresponding load request. |

## 4.3 Data Translation Lookaside Buffer (DTLB)

### 4.3.1 Features

DTLB is a special cache used to keep track of recently used transactions. DTLB contains page table entries that have been most recently used by data access. Given a virtual address, the processor examines the TLB if a page table entry is present (TLB hit), the frame number is retrieved and the real address is formed. If a page table entry is not found in the TLB (TLB miss), the page number is used as an index while processing the page table. TLB first checks if the page is already in main memory, if not in main memory a page fault is issued then the TLB is updated to include the new page entry. 

- Translating VA to PA based on SV48. 

- The non-cacheable state is verified through a 4k range match.
- The occurrence of misalignment, page faults, and PMP is being verified. ***Refer to 4.5.5 EHU for more details.***

***Refer to MMU spec for more detailed features and interface of TLB.***

## 4.4 Load Store Queue (LSQ)

### 4.4.1 Features

- LSQ is used to store load and store instructions.

- LSQ consists of :

  - Load Order Buffer (LOB)
  - Load Hazard Queue (LHQ)
  - Load Speculation Queue (LSPQ)
  - Store Request Queue (SRQ)
  - Store Data Queue (SDQ)
  - Translate Miss Queue (TMQ)
  - Resource Hazard Queue (RHQ)

- LSQ accepts in-order BE allocation, and out-of-order address / data payload input.

- Hazard check for RAR, RAW and WAR.

  

### 4.4.2 Load Order Buffer (LOB)

#### 4.4.2.1 Features

LOB is a storage unit where all in-flight load requests are stored in program order.  It performs checks on all incoming load requests to ensure compliance with memory order rules. FIFO order is followed to record the program order. Due to timing limitations of the selection logic, the queue size is kept small by splitting it into several slices. The FSM transitions are illustrated in the graph below.

- LOB is composed of 4 slices with a FIFO structure, and a global counter (max value == 80) is used to generate maximum 4 LOB IDs.
- Current configuration of each slice: FIFO depth = 20, allocate number = 1, deallocate number = 1.
- LOB accepts in-order BE allocation and record load requests.
- LOB deallocates queue entries and send ROB done / replay info to BE in-order.
- LOB sends speculation confidence update signal to AHP when entry deallocates.
- Each slice's depth is configurable.



#### 4.4.2.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry    | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                                                  |
| :--------------: | :------------------: | :---------------------------: | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| **Control Bits** |                      |                               |                                                              |
|       vld        |          1           |               N               | Entry valid state                                            |
|      pa_vld      |          1           |               N               | DTLB already hit                                             |
|    rob_replay    |          1           |               N               | Need ROB replay                                              |
|     exe_done     |          1           |               N               | Execute done, i.e. has write back                            |
|       excp       |          1           |               N               | Exception exists                                             |
|      awake       |          1           |               N               | All relied branch requests have resolved                     |
|     **Data**     |                      |                               |                                                              |
|     rob_idx      |   RRV64_ROB_PTR_W    |               N               | ROB IDX from BE req w/ wrap bit. Update when allocate.       |
|        va        |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | VA from BE req                                               |
|        pa        |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | PA from BE req                                               |
|     l8b_mask     |          8           |               N               | Address map mask in byte of least 3 bits of address          |
|       rar        |          1           |               N               | RAR hazard found, keep until deallocate                      |
|       conf       |          1           |               N               | Speculation enable, generate by value of speculation confidence |
| non-speculative  |          1           |               N               | Request has detected with ROB replay                         |
|     overflow     |          1           |               N               | RHQ / LHQ / DPB / TMQ full, request sent from LOB            |
|        io        |          1           |               N               | Non-cacheable information                                    |
|        ns        |          1           |               N               | Non-secure information                                       |
|       ecc        |          1           |               N               | ECC error exists. Update when ecc_valid set.                 |
|      snoop       |          1           |               N               | Snoop exists from other core. Update when snp_valid set.     |
|      br_tag      | RRV64_BR_MASK_WIDTH  |               N               | Branch request's tag bit vector which current request relevant |
|      pc_idx      |  RRV64_LSU_PC_IDX_W  |               Y               | Partial of PC for AHP lookup                                 |
|     prd_idx      | RRV64_PHY_REG_ADDR_W |               Y               | PRF index from BE req                                        |
|       uop        |   $size(lsu_op_e)    |               Y               | Sub-op from BE req                                           |

| STATE \ CONTROL BIT | vld  | pa_vld | rob_replay | excp | exe_done |
| :-----------------: | :--: | :----: | :--------: | :--: | :------: |
|        IDLE         |  0   |   x    |     x      |  x   |    x     |
|   PAYLOAD PENDING   |  1   |   0    |     0      |  0   |    0     |
| WRITE BACK PENDING  |  1   |   1    |     0      |  0   |    0     |
|      EXCEPTION      |  1   |   1    |     x      |  1   |    x     |
|     ROB REPLAY      |  1   |   1    |     1      |  0   |    0     |
|    EXECUTE DONE     |  1   |   1    |     x      |  0   |    1     |

<center>Figure 11. An example of BE Allocate LOB Entry</center>



[2] DTLB access hit, physical address valid for L1DC access and hazard checking.

[3] Exception is raised from DTLB. Exception ROB done info sent to BE.  The entry is NOT deallocated until BE ROB flush received.

[4] When a request with an older ROB ID gets PA and sent to check address hazard in LOB, entries with address-overlap and younger ROB ID are considered as having written back overdue data to PRF. ***Refer to 4.4.8. Hazard Check Procedures part for more details.*** 

[5] ECC request received from L1DC matches the current entry's LOB ID.

[6] Current entry is marked RAR, and snoop request received from SCU at an address in the same cacheline as the current entry. ***Refer to 4.4.11.3 Snoop Request Handle Procedures part for more details.***

[7] ROB Replay flag is cleared when LSQ replay request with the same LOB ID is sent to access L1DC. 

[8] ROB Replay request is send to BE when an entry with rob_replay bit set could ROB done. Non-speculative flag bit's set condition is same as ROB replay, but shouldn't cleared when LSQ replay. When entry deallocates, the speculation confidence of AHP decrease with non-speculative set, and the speculation confidence of AHP increase without non-speculative set.

[9] L1DC / RAW forwarding / L2 refill write back signal received.

[10] ROB check pass signal received from LSPQ or entry older than oldest request in SRQ. For IO load requests, it must older than oldest request in SRQ for ROB check pass. 

[11] Each LOB slice could send ROB done and deallocate enable when: 

- Current LOB slice deallocate enable,
- All previous LOB slices with same deallocate wrap bit deallocate enable,
- All subsequent LOB slices with opposite deallocate wrap bit deallocate enable.

Below diagram shows an example for LOB deallocation.

### 4.4.3 Load Hazard Queue (LHQ)

#### 4.4.3.1 Features

LHQ buffers all entries that have dependency (hazard) to other memory requests. Requests with hazards are kept in LHQ and wait for hazard resolution wakeup. Requests that are ready to replay are arbitrated and selected for L1DC access. Due to timing limitations of the selection logic, the queue size is kept small by splitting it into several slices. The FSM transitions are illustrated in the graph below.

- LHQ is composed of 2 slices, and each maintained by a local freelist.

- The slice which request belongs is based on the low bit of LOB index. For example, load with LOB index == 7'b000 0000 belongs to slice 0, and load with LOB index == 7'b000 0111 belongs to slice 1.

- Current configuration of each slice: depth = 32, allocate number = 4, replay / deallocate number = 1.

- LHQ accepts out-of-order allocation from SRQ.

- When LHQ full, new request try to allocate LHQ is marked as need sent to access L1DC from LOB.

- One oldest hazard resolved request is selected to replay each cycle per slice, and deallocate when hand-shake with L1DC successfully.

  

#### 4.4.3.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry    | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                                                  |
| :--------------: | :------------------: | :---------------------------: | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| **Control Bits** |                      |                               |                                                              |
|       vld        |          1           |               N               | Entry valid state                                            |
|      hazard      |          1           |               N               | Hazard isn't resolved                                        |
|     **Data**     |                      |                               |                                                              |
|     lob_idx      | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W  |               N               | LOB index when BE allocate LOB. Update when allocate.        |
|      vaddr       |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | VA from BE req                                               |
|      paddr       |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | PA from BE req                                               |
|     lsb_mask     |          8           |               N               | Byte mask mapped by low 3 bits of address                    |
|   raw_stq_tag    |    SRQ_TAG_WIDTH     |               N               | Corresponding SRQ entry, one-hot. Update when RAW hazard found. |
|       rob        |   RRV64_ROB_PTR_W    |               Y               | ROB IDX from BE req w/ wrap bit                              |
|     prd_idx      | RRV64_PHY_REG_ADDR_W |               Y               | PRF index from BE req                                        |
|       uop        |   $size(lsu_op_e)    |               Y               | Sub-op from BE req                                           |
|        fp        |          1           |               Y               | Request is float point                                       |
|       hlsv       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlsv, for tlb                                     |
|       hlvx       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlvx, for tlb                                     |
|       dtcm       |          1           |               Y               | Request is dtcm, for dcache                                  |

| STATE \ CONTROL BIT | vld  | hazard |
| :-----------------: | :--: | :----: |
|        IDLE         |  0   |   x    |
|   WAIT FOR WAKEUP   |  1   |   1    |
|   REPLAY PENDING    |  1   |   0    |

[1] State revert to *IDLE* when BE ROB flush signal is set, regardless of the current state. LHQ is allocated when RAW is detected in SRQ and records the SRQ tag (bit vector) of RAW hit entry.

[2] SRQ broadcasts the RAW awake signal when:

* New data payload input from BE.

* Store request is sent to access L1DC.

  Waked SRQ tag bit is cleared when corresponding awake signal received.

[3] Entry could be selected to replay when all RAW SRQ tag bits cleared.

[4] Entry with oldest ROB index is selected to replay, and entry deallocate from LHQ.

### 4.4.4 Load Speculation Queue (LSPQ)

#### 4.4.4.1 Features

LSPQ buffers all load requests that have address-unknown store request with older ROB index. Potential RAW make these load requests in the speculation state. Speculation requests are kept in LSPQ and wait for wakeup when relevant store requests get PA. A ROB check pass signal is sent to LOB when speculation resolved. Due to timing limitations of the selection logic, the queue size is kept small by splitting it into several slices which same as LOB slices. The FSM transitions are illustrated in the graph below.

- LSPB is composed of 2 slices, and each maintained by a local freelist.

- The slice which request belongs is based on the low bit of LOB index. 

- Current configuration of each slice: depth = 16, allocate number = 4, ROB check pass / deallocation number = 1.

- LSPQ accepts out-of-order allocation from SRQ.

- When LSPQ full, new request try to allocate LSPQ is marked as need to be sent to access L1DC from LOB.

- One oldest speculation resolved request is selected to send ROB check pass signal and deallocte each cycle per slice.

  

#### 4.4.4.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry   | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                                           |
| :--------------: | :-----------------: | :---------------------------: | ----------------------------------------------------- |
| **Control Bits** |                     |                               |                                                       |
|       vld        |          1          |               N               | Entry valid state                                     |
|   speculation    |          1          |               N               | Speculation isn't resolved                            |
|     **Data**     |                     |                               |                                                       |
|     lob_idx      | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W |               N               | LOB index when BE allocate LOB. Update when allocate. |
|  specu_stq_tag   |    SRQ_TAG_WIDTH    |               N               | SRQ tag bit vector. Update when speculation found.    |

### 4.4.5 Store Request Queue (SRQ)

#### 4.4.5.1 Features

SRQ buffers the address payload of all entries that have not been committed yet. Instructions that are ready to commit are moved to STB.

- SRQ is composed of 4 slices with FIFO structure, and a global counter (max value == 64) is used to generate maximum 4 SRQ IDs.
- Current configuration of each slice: FIFO depth = 16, allocate number = 2, deallocate number = 1.
- SRQ accepts in-order BE allocation and record store / AMO / fence requests.
- SRQ sends normal store requests to STB, AMO & IO requests to L1DC, and fence request to fence control.
- SRQ executes instructions in SRQ, deallocate queue entry and send ROB done info to BE in-order.
- Each slice's depth is configurable.



#### 4.4.5.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry   | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                                                  |
| :--------------: | :-----------------: | :---------------------------: | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| **Control Bits** |                     |                               |                                                              |
|       vld        |          1          |               N               | Entry valid state                                            |
|     pld_vld      |          1          |               N               | Address payload received                                     |
|      pa_vld      |          1          |               N               | DTLB already hit                                             |
|     data_vld     |          1          |               N               | Data received from BE                                        |
|       war        |          1          |               N               | WAR hazard exists                                            |
|       waw        |          1          |               N               | WAW hazard exists                                            |
|     dc_sent      |          1          |               N               | Request has sent to L1DC, for make sure IO and AMO execute done. |
|      awake       |          1          |               N               | All relied branch requests have resolved                     |
|       excp       |          1          |               N               | Exception exists                                             |
|     **Data**     |                     |                               |                                                              |
|       rob        |   RRV64_ROB_PTR_W   |               N               | ROB IDX from BE req w/ wrap bit                              |
|      vaddr       |  RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | VA from BE req                                               |
|      paddr       |  RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               N               | PA from BE req                                               |
|     lsb_mask     |          8          |               N               | Byte mask mapped by low 3 bits of address                    |
|    block_req     |          1          |               N               | Request is IO or AMO, need more deallocate check             |
|      vector      |          1          |               N               | Request is 512-bits vector request                           |
|   sdq_vec_idx    |    SDQ_VEC_IDX_W    |               N               | Index of associated SDQ 512-bits vector entry                |
|     amo_lrsc     |          1          |               N               | Request is AMO                                               |
|     acquire      |          1          |               N               | Request has require notation                                 |
|     release      |          1          |               N               | Request has release notation                                 |
|        io        |          1          |               N               | Non-cacheable information                                    |
|        ns        |          1          |               N               | Non-secure information                                       |
|      br_tag      | RRV64_BR_MASK_WIDTH |               N               | Branch request's tag bit vector which current request relevant |
|   war_lob_tag    |    LOB_TAG_WIDTH    |               N               | Corresponding WAR lob entry                                  |
|   waw_srq_tag    |    SRQ_TAG_WIDTH    |               N               | Corresponding WAW srq entry                                  |

<center>Figure 18. SRQ (Entry i) State Transition Diagram</center>

| STATE \ CONTROL BIT | vld  | pld_vld | pa_vld | war  | data_vld | awake | excp | dc_sent |
| :-----------------: | :--: | :-----: | :----: | :--: | :------: | :---: | :--: | :-----: |
|        IDLE         |  0   |    x    |   x    |  x   |    x     |   x   |  x   |    x    |
|   PAYLOAD PENDING   |  1   |    0    |   0    |  0   |    0     |   0   |  0   |    0    |
|  EXECUTION PENDING  |  1   |    1    |   1    |  0   |    0     |   0   |  0   |    0    |
|   HAZARD PENDING    |  1   |    1    |   1    |  1   |    x     |   x   |  0   |    0    |
|      EXCEPTION      |  1   |    1    |   1    |  x   |    x     |   x   |  1   |    0    |
|      INFLIGHT       |  1   |    1    |   1    |  0   |    1     |   1   |  0   |    1    |

[1] State revert to *IDLE* when BE ROB flush signal is set, regardless of the current state. Allocate in-order during BE dispatch stage, and SRQ return allocated SRQ IDs to BE.

[2] DTLB access hit, and physical address valid for hazard checking.

[3] Exception is raised from DTLB. Exception ROB done info sent to BE.  The entry is NOT deallocated until BE ROB flush received.

[4] PAs of in-flight requests are checked against LOB / SRQ, and WAR / WAW hazard found.

[5] Hazard wakeup signal received from LOB / SRQ, and index matched for this SRQ entry.

[6] When the read pointer points to an awakened entry with data has inputted, and all entries of the LOB must have a younger ROB ID to maintain order. Alternatively, ROB replay / snoop / RAR / exception flag bit of LOB entries with older ROB ID isn't set, corresponding request is sent to perform.  

[7] For normal store requests, entry is deallocated and ROB done is sent to BE when successfully hand-shake with STB cycle. DPB handle IO store request and return execute done signal. AMO request execute done response is sent from L1DC after execution completed. Fence request flush process controlled by FSM. The deallocation logic is same as LOB.



### 4.4.6 Store Data Queue (SDQ)

#### 4.4.6.1 Features

SDQ buffers the data payload of all entries that have not yet been committed. Instructions that are ready to be committed is moved to STB. Each 64-bits entry in the SDQ corresponding to an entry in the SRQ and indexed by the SRQ ID when storing data input. There are 4 extra entries for 512-bits vector reqeust data.

- SDQ is composed of 4 slices with FIFO structure, and indexed by SRQ ID.
- Current configuration of each slice: FIFO depth = 16, input number = 4, deallocate number = 1.
- SDQ accepts BE data payload out-of-order, and back-pressures one input channel when two requests access the same slice.
- SDQ outputs in-order when request with same ID is sent from SRQ.
- Each slice's depth is configurable.



#### 4.4.6.2 Datatype

|    Data Payload    |   Width per Entry   | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                     |
| :----------------: | :-----------------: | :---------------------------: | ------------------------------- |
| **64-bits entry**  |                     |                               |                                 |
|        data        |  RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               Y               | Store data from BE req          |
|        uop         |   $size(lsu_op_e)   |               Y               | Sub-op from BE req              |
|        amo         |          1          |               Y               | Request is AMO except LR and SC |
|         lr         |          1          |               Y               | Request is Load-Reserved        |
|         sc         |          1          |               Y               | Request is Store-Conditional    |
|         fp         |          1          |               Y               | Request is float point          |
|        hlsv        |          1          |               Y               | Request is hlsv, for tlb        |
|        hlvx        |          1          |               Y               | Request is hlvx, for tlb        |
| **512-bits entry** |                     |                               |                                 |
|       valid        |          1          |               N               | Entry valid state               |
|      srq_idx       | RRV64_LSU_SRQ_IDX_W |               N               | Relevant SRQ index              |
|        data        |         512         |               Y               | Store data from VBE req         |

### 4.4.7 Translate Miss Queue (TMQ)

#### 4.4.7.1 Features

TMQ stores DTLB translation missed requests. When DTLB miss information is received, corresponding requests are sent to this queue. Upon receiving a wakeup (refill) signal, the awakened entry is selected and replayed to both DTLB and L1DC (only load request).

- TMQ is composed of 2 slices, and each maintained by a local freelist.
- The slice which request belongs is based on the low bit of LOB index. 
- Current configuration of each slice: FIFO depth = 16, allocate number = 4, replay / deallocate number = 1.
- Entry of TMQ is allocated and updated when DTLB output PA payloads.
- One oldest awaked request is selected to replay each cycle per slice, and deallocate when hand-shake with L1DC successfully.



#### 4.4.7.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry    | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                               |
| :--------------: | :------------------: | :---------------------------: | ----------------------------------------- |
| **Control Bits** |                      |                               |                                           |
|       vld        |          1           |               N               | Entry valid state                         |
|    dtlb_miss     |          1           |               N               | DTLB miss, wait for DTLB refill wakeup    |
|     **Data**     |                      |                               |                                           |
|       rob        |   RRV64_ROB_PTR_W    |               Y               | ROB IDX from BE req w/ wrap bit           |
|     lob_idx      | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W  |               Y               | LOB index when BE allocate LOB            |
|     prd_idx      | RRV64_PHY_REG_ADDR_W |               Y               | PRF from BE req                           |
|      vaddr       |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               Y               | VA from BE req                            |
|     lsb_mask     |          8           |               Y               | Byte mask mapped by low 3 bits of address |
|       uop        |   $size(lsu_op_e)    |               Y               | Sub-op from BE req                        |
|        fp        |          1           |               Y               | Request is float point                    |
|       hlsv       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlsv, for tlb                  |
|       hlvx       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlvx, for tlb                  |

### 4.4.8 Resource Hazard Queue (RHQ)

#### 4.4.8.1 Features

RHQ buffers requests with L1DC / iPRF no-ready, L1DC bank conflict, MSHR full, and other replay condition caused of resource hazard. Request stored in RHQ could be sent to replay without any wakeup.

- RHQ is composed of 4 slices with FIFO structure.
- The slice which request belongs is based on the pipeline channel. 
- Current configuration of each slice: FIFO depth = 4, allocate number = 4, deallocate number = 1.
- Entry of RHQ is allocated and updated when bank conflict detected and PA payloads received.
- RHQ deallocates queue entry and sends replay request in-order.



#### 4.4.9.2 Datatype

|   Data Payload   |   Width per Entry    | Acceptable for storage in RAM | Description                               |
| :--------------: | :------------------: | :---------------------------: | ----------------------------------------- |
| **Control Bits** |                      |                               |                                           |
|       vld        |          1           |               N               | Entry valid state                         |
|     **Data**     |                      |                               |                                           |
|       rob        |   RRV64_ROB_PTR_W    |               Y               | ROB IDX from BE req w/ wrap bit           |
|     lob_idx      | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W  |               Y               | LOB index when BE allocate LOB            |
|     prd_idx      | RRV64_PHY_REG_ADDR_W |               Y               | PRF from BE req                           |
|      vaddr       |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               Y               | VA from BE req                            |
|      paddr       |   RRV64_REG_DATA_W   |               Y               | PA from BE req                            |
|     lsb_mask     |          8           |               Y               | Byte mask mapped by low 3 bits of address |
|       uop        |   $size(lsu_op_e)    |               Y               | Sub-op from BE req                        |
|        fp        |          1           |               Y               | Request is float point                    |
|       hlsv       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlsv, for tlb                  |
|       hlvx       |          1           |               Y               | Request is hlvx, for tlb                  |

### 4.4.9 Hazard Check Procedures

Hazard check procedures below is in RVWMO mode by default, and the mark of the hazard flag bit in RVTSO mode is specifically signed out as RVTSO_RELAXED / RVTSO_STRICT mode enable / disable. Furthermore, the ordering of AMO (acquire & release) is shown in *4.4.10.2 Acquire & Release Handle Procedures*.

#### 4.4.9.1 RAW Handle Procedures

**Load request to SRQ**

- When PA of load request is sent to access L1DC, RAW is detected under the following conditions:
  - SRQ entry valid enable,
  - SRQ entry has an older ROB ID,
  - One of the following situations occurs:
    - Address hazard / overlap.
    - PA of SRQ entry is not ready, but predictive result of AHP is valid.
    - RVTSO_STRICT mode enable.
  
- The RAW check result is sent to LHQ, RAW flag bit is updated and SRQ ID of older SRQ entry is recorded as RAW SRQ ID.
- Younger load requests with RAW are killed from L1DC pipeline. 
- Wakeup signal is sent to LHQ when SRQ entry deallocates, and the corresponding RAW SRQ ID bit is cleared.
- When all RAW SRQ ID bits of a LHQ entry are cleared, the RAW flag is also cleared and a LSQ replay request is sent to access L1DC.

**Store request to LOB**

- When store request firstly gets PA from DTLB, un-detected RAW is found under the following conditions:
  - LOB entry valid enable,
  - LOB entry has a younger ROB ID,
  - RVTSO_STRICT mode disable.
  - Address hazard / overlap.
- ROB replay flag bit of the LOB entry is set when an un-detected RAW is found.
- ROB replay flag bit could be cleared when the corresponding load request performs LSQ replay.
- ROB replay signal is sent to BE when an entry with ROB replay flag bit set deallocate.

For example, an Store A - Load B pair, when younger load request get PA from DTLB: 

| Store A - Load B Address hazard? | AHP predict hazard hit? | Store A address is inclusive to Load B? | Store A PA ready? | Store A data ready? | Load B need LSQ replay | Load B need ROB replay |
| :------------------------------: | :---------------------: | :-------------------------------------: | :---------------: | :-----------------: | :--------------------: | :--------------------: |
|                Y                 |          Y / N          |                    Y                    |         Y         |          Y          |   N (RAW forwarding)   |           N            |
|                Y                 |          Y / N          |                    N                    |         Y         |          Y          |           Y            |           N            |
|                Y                 |          Y / N          |                  Y / N                  |         Y         |          N          |           Y            |           N            |
|                Y                 |            Y            |                  Y / N                  |         N         |        Y / N        |           Y            |           N            |
|                Y                 |            N            |                  Y / N                  |         N         |        Y / N        |           N            |           Y            |
|                N                 |            Y            |                  Y / N                  |         N         |        Y / N        |           Y            |           N            |
|                N                 |            N            |                  Y / N                  |       Y / N       |        Y / N        |           N            |           N            |



#### 4.4.9.2 RAR Handle Procedures

**Load request to LOB**

- When PA of load request is sent to access L1DC, RAR flag bit of LOB entry is set under the following conditions:
  - LOB entry valid enable,
  - LOB entry has a younger ROB ID,
  - LOB entry NOT belongs to an IO request,
  - Address hazard / overlap.
- And RAR of in-flight load request detected under the following conditions:
  - LOB entry valid enable,
  - LOB entry has an older ROB ID,
  - LOB entry NOT belongs to an IO request,
  - Address hazard / overlap.
- RAR flag bit of in-flight load request in LOB is set when RAR detected.
- ROB replay flag bit of LOB entry is set under the following conditions:
  - Snoop flag bit of LOB is set. ***Please refer to 4.4.10.3 Snoop Request Handle Procedures for more info about snoop flag bit set.***
  - One of the following situations occurs:
    - RAR flag bit of LOB is set,
    - RVTSO_RELAXED mode enable.
- ROB replay flag bit could be cleared when the corresponding load request performs LSQ replay.
- ROB replay signal is sent to BE when an entry with ROB replay flag bit set deallocate.

For example, an Load A - Load B pair, when snoop request which has same cacheline with Load B input to LSQ:

| Load A - Load B Address hazard? | Load A PA ready? | Load B PA ready? | Load B marked snoop |            Load B need LSQ replay            | Load B need ROB replay |
| :-----------------------------: | :--------------: | :--------------: | :-----------------: | :------------------------------------------: | :--------------------: |
|                N                |      Y / N       |      Y / N       |          Y          |                      N                       |           N            |
|                Y                |        N         |        N         |          N          | If LD1 PA ready within subsequent two cycles |           N            |
|                Y                |        Y         |        N         |          N          | If LD1 PA ready within subsequent two cycles |           N            |
|                Y                |        N         |        Y         |          Y          |                      N                       |           Y            |
|                Y                |        Y         |        Y         |          Y          |                      N                       |           Y            |



#### 4.4.9.3 WAR Handle Procedures

**Load request to SRQ**

- When PA of load request is sent to access L1DC, WAR is detected under the following conditions:
  - SRQ entry valid enable,
  - SRQ entry has a younger ROB ID,
  - One of the following situations occurs:
    - Address hazard / overlap.
    - RVTSO_STRICT mode enable.
- WAR flag bit of SRQ entry is set, and LOB ID of in-flight load request is recorded as WAR LOB ID.
- Wakeup signal is sent to SRQ when LOB entry deallocate, and the corresponding WAR LOB ID bit is cleared.
- When all WAR LOB ID bits of a SRQ entry are cleared, the WAR flag is also cleared and request could be sent to execute.

**Store request to LOB**

- When store request firstly gets PA from DTLB, WAR is detected under the following conditions:
  - LOB entry valid enable,
  - LOB entry has an older ROB ID,
  - One of the following situations occurs:
    - Address hazard / overlap.
    - RVTSO_STRICT mode enable.
- WAR flag bit of SRQ entry is set, and LOB ID of in-flight load request is recorded as WAR LOB ID.
- Wakeup signal is sent to SRQ when LOB entry deallocate, and the corresponding WAR LOB ID bit is cleared.
- When all WAR LOB ID bits of a SRQ entry are cleared, the WAR flag is also cleared and request could be sent to execute.



#### 4.4.9.4 WAW Handle Procedures

- When PA of store request is sent to access L1DC, WAW flag bit of SRQ entry is set under the following conditions:
  - SRQ entry valid enable,
  - SRQ entry has a younger ROB ID,
  - SRQ entry NOT belongs to an IO request,
  - Address hazard / overlap.
- And WAW of in-flight store request detected under the following conditions:
  - SRQ entry valid enable,
  - SRQ entry has an older ROB ID,
  - SRQ entry NOT belongs to an IO request,
  - Address hazard / overlap.
- WAW flag bit of in-flight store request in SRQ is set when WAW detected, and SRQ ID of older SRQ entry is recorded as WAW SRQ ID.
- Wakeup signal is set when SRQ entry deallocates, and the corresponding WAW SRQ ID bit is cleared.
- When all WAW SRQ ID bits of a SRQ entry are cleared, the WAW flag is also cleared and request could be sent to execute.



#### 4.4.9.5 Same Cycle Hazard Check

**RAW in LHQ**

- For example, two requests of 4 DTLB response channels with PA are load and store, respectively.
- Address hazard check like load request to SRQ, and RAW hit.
- Younger load request is marked as RAW hazard in LHQ.
- Younger load request with RAW is killed from L1DC pipeline. 
- Corresponding LHQ entry could be sent to replay when hazard resolve.

**RAR in LHQ**

- For example, two requests of 4 DTLB response channels with PA are both load.
- Address hazard check like load request to LOB, and RAR hit.
- Younger load request is marked as RAR hazard both in LHQ and LOB.
- Younger load request with RAR is killed from L1DC pipeline. 
- Corresponding LHQ entry could be sent to replay when hazard resolve.

**WAR in SRQ**

- For example, two requests of 4 DTLB response channels with PA are load and store, respectively.
- Address hazard check like load request to SRQ, and WAR hit.
- Younger store request is marked as WAR hazard in SRQ.
- Corresponding SRQ entry could be sent to execute when hazard resolve.

**WAW in SRQ**

- For example, two requests of 4 DTLB response channels with PA are both store.
- Address hazard check like store request to SRQ, and WAW hit.
- Younger store request is marked as WAW hazard in SRQ.
- Corresponding SRQ entry could be sent to execute when hazard resolve.



### 4.4.10 Memory Ordering

#### 4.4.10.1 Ordering Rules

P800 follows the standard RVWMO with the additional support for RVTSO extension to be compatible with x86 TSO programs. In TSO mode, only load to store order is relaxed, all other combinations are strictly ordered.

<center>Figure 25. RVWMO Memory Consistency Model for P800</center>



RVWMO ordering Rules Format below are presented as INST0 - INST1, indicating INST1 trying to bypass INST0.


- **LD - LD bypass/reorder:**
  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED (only if store to same address from other cores observed or config register set)
  - No address conflict:  ALLOWED
- **LD - ST bypass/reorder:**
  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED
  - No address conflict:  ALLOWED
- **ST - LD bypass/reorder:**

  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED
  - No address conflict:  ALLOWED
- **ST - ST bypass/reorder:**
  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED
  - No address conflict:  ALLOWED (reordered in STB)
- **IO bypass/reorder:**
  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED (between IO)
  - No address conflict:  NOT ALLOWED (between IO)
- **FENCE/AMO bypass/reorder:**
  - Address conflict:        NOT ALLOWED
  - No address conflict:  Depend on acquire & release annotation



#### 4.4.10.2 Acquire & Release Handle Procedures

Because in RVWMO mode, acquire and release annotations belongs to AMO requests which are recorded in SRQ & SDQ, and all load and store requests are regarded as acquire / release in RVTSO mode, i.e. additional annotations are unnecessary, acquire - release handle procedures reuse partial store requests hazard check logic.

Acquire and release annotations are recorded in stage of BE allocate SRQ, to ensure timely hazard check and avoid to raise ROB replay. Because of the FIFO structure of SRQ, the ordering of store - AMO and AMO - AMO are kept. More handling rules between load and AMO requests in RVWMO mode are shown below:

| INST0 is load ? | INST0 is acquire ? | INST0 is release ? | INST1 is load ? | INST1 is acquire ? | INST1 is release ? |                      Handle Procedures                       |
| :-------------: | :----------------: | :----------------: | :-------------: | :----------------: | :----------------: | :----------------------------------------------------------: |
|        Y        |        ---         |        ---         |        N        |         Y          |         N          |        Hazard check procedure is executed as normal.         |
|        Y        |        ---         |        ---         |        N        |       Y / N        |         Y          | INST1 is marked as WAR, and sent to STB when INST0 ROB done. |
|        N        |         Y          |       Y / N        |        Y        |        ---         |        ---         | INST1 is marked as RAW, and LSQ replay when INST0 ROB done.  |
|        N        |         N          |         Y          |        Y        |        ---         |        ---         |        Hazard check procedure is executed as normal.         |



#### 4.4.10.3 Snoop Request Handle Procedures

When other core execute memory access request, snoop signal sent to current core. In LSU, L1DC and LOB handle snoop request.

- **L1DC**
  - ***Refer to L1DC spec for detailed features and interface.***

- **LOB**
  - 3 orders for load are allowed :
    - Older load get data before snoop, and younger load get data before snoop.
    - Older load get data after snoop, and younger load get data after snoop.
    - Older load get data before snoop, and younger load get data after snoop.
  - Hand shake signal of SCU & L1DC and snoop request address input and delay to next cycle used for timing.
  - When hand shake success, snoop request address compare with PA of all LOB entries, and mark all entry in same cacheline as snoop hit by set snoop flag bit of LOB.
  - When hand shake success, snoop request address also recorded in a shift buffer with depth = 3. All in-flight load request compare with snoop request address in shift buffer when PA sent to access L1DC, and set snoop flag bit of LOB when snoop hit.
  - ROB replay flag bit of LOB entry is set when both RAR flag bit and snoop flag bit are set in LOB.
  - When PA of in-flight load request matches with snoop recording shift buffer, sent flag bit of in-flight load request in LHQ is clear.
  - In-flight load requests with RAR are killed from L1DC pipeline, and current request could be chose to access L1DC in next cycle.
  - Snoop flag bit is cleared when ROB replay flag bit is set, otherwise LSQ replay can't clear ROB replay flag. Snoop flag bit and ROB replay flag bit could be set when another snoop hit after LSQ replay perform.
  - ROB replay signal is sent to BE when entry with ROB replay flag bit set deallocate.



#### 4.4.10.4 RVWMO Implementation

**Preserved Program Order (PPO)**: If request 0 (A) appears before request 1 (B) in program order, and A & B match one of the patterns below, then A appears before B in global memory order.

| PPO Rules                                                    | Implementation                                               |
| ------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Rule 1: If A and store B access the overlapping address, then A must appear before B in global memory order. | Load - Store: The WAR check keep the ordering of load - store. Store - Store: The FIFO structure of SRQ ensure that store requests sent to perform in-order, and store buffer (STB) merge data of requests with overlapping address in-order. |
| Rule 2: Overlapping address load-load ordering is maintained with two exceptions: both return values come from the same store; B forwards from a store M between A and B in program order. | The load-load ordering is kept by snoop process in LOB, and two allowed exceptions is covered by 3 orders for load are allowed in *4.4.10.3 Snoop Request Handle Procedures* LOB part. |
| Rule 3: A load B cannot determine its return value by forwarding from an atomic memory operation (AMO) or store-conditional operation (SC) that has not yet become globally visible. | The RAW check keep the ordering of load - AMO, and RAW forwarding is not allowed from entry belongs to the AMO request. |
| Rule 4: If a fence M between A and B, then A must appear before B in global memory order. | The ordering of fence request is kept by hazard check of RAW and the FIFO structure of SRQ. |
| Rule 5: All operations following an AMO or LR/SC with acquire annotation in program order also following it in global memory order. | Acquire - Load: The RAW check with extra acquire flag bit keep the ordering of acquire - load. Acquire - Store: The FIFO structure of SRQ ensure that AMO & store requests sent to perform in-order, and store could be sent to STB after preceding AMO request execution completed. |
| Rule 6: All operations preceding an AMO or LR/SC with release annotation in program order also precede it in global memory order. | Load - Release: The WAR check with extra release flag bit keep the ordering of load - release. Store - Release: The FIFO structure of SRQ ensure that AMO & store requests sent to perform in-order, and the AMO control ensure STB is flushed to L1DC before AMO execution. |
| Rule 7: An AMO or LR/SC with release annotation that precedes an AMO or LR/SC with acquire annotation in program order also precedes it in global memory order. | The FIFO structure of SRQ ensure that AMO request sent to perform in-order, and the AMO control ensure only one AMO request in-flight. |
| Rule 8: A load-reserve (LR) operation determines its value before the paired store-conditional (SC) becomes globally visible. | The FIFO structure of SRQ ensure that LR - SC sent to perform in-order, and the AMO control ensure only one LR / SC request in-flight. |
| Rule 9~11: If B has an address / control / data dependency on A, then A precedes B in global memory order. | The ordering is kept by BE.                                  |
| Rule 12: B follows M in program order, and M has an address dependency on A, then A precedes B in global memory order. | The ordering is kept by BE, it's derivative of Rule 9~11.    |
| Rule 13: B returns a value from an earlier store M in the same hart, and M has an address or data dependency on A, then A precedes B in global memory order. | The ordering is kept by BE, it's derivative of Rule 9~11.    |



#### 4.4.10.5 RVTSO Implementation (Ssdtso Extension Supported)

**Overview**

For RVTSO implementation, two 1-bit CSR registers are used to enable relaxed RVTSO (RVTSO_RELAXED) implementation or strict RVTSO (RVTSO_STRICT) implementation. RVTSO_STRICT mode has higher priority when both mode enable and can be enabled by external input control signal.

| Program order     | Implementation                                               |
| ----------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Load A - Load B   | RVTSO_RELAXED Enable: As shown in figure 18; RVTSO_STRICT Enable: All load request is performed like IO load request, the first L1DC access is killed and request actually sent to L1DC from LOB when it's the oldest instruction of LOB. |
| Load A - Store B  | The deallocation rule of SRQ and the retirement rule of ROB ensure Store B follows Load A in global memory order. |
| Store A - Load B  | More additional limits than RVWMO mode are unnecessary.      |
| Store A - Store B | SRQ and STB are forced FIFO order.                           |

**Motivation**

* The goal is to support TSO memory order, with:
  * Functional correctness
  * Minimized performance lost
* RVTSO_STRICT: To ensure functional correctness
  * Serialize all memory access requests
  * Safety if memory order fails in other modes
* RVTSO_RELAXED: To minimize performance lost
  * Serialize store writeback to L1DC only
  * Aggressive relaxation under TSO mode to provide best performance
* Both modes are proposed to be supported
  * RVTSO_RELAXED mode as the primary mode for high performance
  * RVTSO_STRICT is only reserved as the backup mode as a fail safe 

**Overall Pipeline**

* RVWMO
  * Load: Full pipeline
  * Store: Full SRQ & STB
* RVTSO_RELAXED
  * Load: Bypass RAR address check
  * Store: Bypass STB
* RVTSO_STRICT
  * Load: Bypass hazard check & LHQ
  * Store: Bypass STB

**Mode Switching**

TSO mode activation/deactivation is controlled by 2 CSR bits. RVTSO_STRICT can be enabled by external input control signal.

* LSU in RVWMO/RVTSO mode
* Wait for LSU idle
* Wait for STB empty (all writeback to L1DC)
* CSR instruction to change mode
* Mode swtiched to RVTSO/RVWMO
* Following load/store issuing



### 4.4.11 LSQ Top Interface 

| Signal                       | Group                     | Width/Group              | I/O  | Description                         |
| ---------------------------- | ------------------------- | ------------------------ | :--: | ----------------------------------- |
| clk                          | 1                         | 1                        |  I   | Clock                               |
| rstn                         | 1                         | 1                        |  I   | Async reset                         |
| flush_lsq_vld_i              | 1                         | 1                        |  I   | Indicates ROB flush                 |
| cfg_lsu_tso_en               | 1                         | 1                        |  I   | config reg, TSO mode                |
| lsq_empty_o                  | 1                         | 1                        |  O   | Indicates LSQ empty                 |
|                              |                           |                          |      |                                     |
| **//Allocate Stage**         |                           |                          |      |                                     |
| be_lsu_lsq_alloc_valid       | RRV64_ISSUE_NUM           | 1                        |  I   | BE requests for allocate LSQ entry  |
| be_lsu_lsq_alloc_is_load     | RRV64_ISSUE_NUM           | 1                        |  I   | Distinguish LD/ST                   |
| lsu_be_lsq_alloc_ready       | RRV64_ISSUE_NUM           | 1                        |  O   | LSQ available for allocate          |
| lsu_be_lsq_alloc_pld_lob_idx | RRV64_ISSUE_NUM           | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W      |  O   | Allocated lob ID in binary          |
| lsu_be_lsq_alloc_pld_stq_idx | RRV64_ISSUE_NUM           | RRV64_LSU_SRQ_IDX_W      |  O   | Allocated SRQ ID in binary          |
|                              |                           |                          |      |                                     |
| **//LD & ST Addr Payload**   |                           |                          |      |                                     |
| dtlb_lsq_valid               | RRV64_LSU_ADDR_PIPE_NUM*2 |                          |  I   | Payload from DTLB & BUF valid       |
| **dtlb_lsq_pld**             | RRV64_LSU_ADDR_PIPE_NUM*2 | dtlb_lsu_dc_pld_t        |  I   | Payload from DTLB & BUF             |
| >>*rob_idx*                  |                           | RRV64_ROB_PTR_W          |      | w/ wrap bit on MSB                  |
| >>*lob_idx*                  |                           | RRV64_LSU_LOB_IDX_W      |      |                                     |
| >>*stq_idx*                  |                           | RRV64_LSU_SRQ_IDX_W      |      |                                     |
| >>*sub_op*                   |                           | RRV64_SUB_OP_W           |      |                                     |
| >>*addr*                     |                           | RRV64_REG_DATA_W         |      |                                     |
| >>*alias_bit*                |                           | RRV64_ALIAS_BIT_W        |      |                                     |
| >>*prd*                      |                           | RRV64_INT_PHY_REG_ADDR_W |      |                                     |
| >>*alias_bit*                |                           | RRV64_ALIAS_BIT_W        |      | Alias bit width currently 1         |
| >>*is_nc*                    |                           | 1                        |      | Non-cacheable                       |
| >>*is_sr*                    |                           | 1                        |      | Non-secure (secure region)          |
| >>*be_ch*                    |                           | 1                        |      | BE issue channel number             |
| >>*from_lsq*                 |                           | 1                        |      | Indicate replay from LSQ            |
| >>*pa_valid*                 |                           | 1                        |      | DTLB hit and PA valid               |

## 4.5 MISC

**Stage0 --  Replay arbitration**

* For timing, replay arbitration take an extra stage.
* Priority: 4x RHQ replay > 2x TMQ replay > 2x LHQ replay.
* Select the first four replay requests from eight replay sources, register to next stage.

**Stage1 --  Request arbitration**

* LOB replay do arbitrate with replay channel with lowest priority.
* Each new requests from AGU do arbitrate with corresponding replay channel.



### 4.5.2 ROB Done Control

Send ROB done info to BE. 

- 8 channel
  - channel 0 ~ 3 : Load (include io)
  - channel 4 ~ 7 : Store (include io)
  - channel 8 : AMO (all type) and fence
  - channel 9 : Exception
- Load request set ROB done when entry deallocate from LOB.
- Store request set ROB done when store request is sent to STB.
- AMO request set ROB done when request is executed done. Fence request set ROB done when flush is completed.
- Exception set ROB done when all exception type checks are completed.



### 4.5.3 AMO Control

All AMO requests are allocated in SRQ and SDQ (in the case of sfence.vma where data is needed), and execute in program order. 

When an AMO request is in-flight, other memory operation is blocked according to the acquire or release notation of this AMO request.

### 4.5.4 Fence Control

Fence functionality is also implemented, including standard fence, fencei, and sfence. The handling of the fence requests is split into two parts: memory barrier and flush control. The memory barrier part is incorporated into the hazard checking & waiting mechanism similar to a normal memory instructions with acquire / release annotations. The fence is allocated in SRQ in the dispatch stage, predecessor and successor memory operations is checked and marked wait status according to the acquire or release notation of the fence.

The flush part is handled by the fence flush control unit, and follows the sequence below:

- fencei sequence:  L1DCache -> L2Cache  -> L1ICache & BPU
- sfence.vma type: ALL, ASID, VA, ASID_VA
- sfence.vma sequence: DTLB -> ITLB & BPU -> L2TLB -> L1ICache

### 4.5.5 Exception Handling Unit (EHU)

EHU is used to pass various possible exceptions from VA, PA, and DTLB.

- **Misalign**

  Load/Store address must be aligned (starting from a aligned address) according to its operation type. Result of misalign exception check is generated in DC0.

  - Byte: no misalignment possible
  - Half Word: bit [0] ~= 0
  - Word: bit [1:0] ~= 0
  - Double Word: bit [2:0] ~= 0

- **TLB**

  Page fault & access fault, directly obtained from DTLB. Result of TLB exception check is generated in DC1.

- **PMP**

  PA is checked against the start and end addresses stored in pmpconfig register to determine if the address has read, write, or execute permissions. Result of PMP exception check is generated in DC2.

  ***Refer to "The RISC-V Instruction Set Manual Volume II: Privileged Architecture" chapter 3.6 for more details.***



## 4.6 L1DC

The L1 data cache handles load store requests from load store queues. 

***Refer to L1DC spec for detailed features and interface.***



## 4.7 Vector Extension (RISC-V Vector Extension V1.0 Supported)

For vector extension supported, two 512-bits load requests or one 512-bits store request is accepted from Vector Backend (VBE).

* Unit-stride and most of stride type vector requests are merged to 512-bits memory access.
* Partial stride and index type vector request use 64-bits memory access channel.
* ***Refer to Vector spec for more details of the mechanism of vector request merged.***
* Each vector merged memory access request need allocate one LOB / SRQ entry.
* Vector merged memory access requests reuse the decomposed queue and pipeline of LSU.
